document.title: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards for Mathematics

DE09ACE642EC48C0BF47BE6DEC4EBF01.description:
Justify the sum and difference formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve
problems.

4C4874D3A65343E9B8DCDDB9AE5E04C9.description:
Justify the Pythagorean, even/odd, and cofunction identities for sine and cosine using their unit
circle definitions and symmetries of the unit circle and use the Pythagorean identity to find sin ùê¥,
cos ùê¥, or tan ùê¥, given sin ùê¥, cos ùê¥, or tan ùê¥, and the quadrant of the angle.

0FDD8E1CE89D49678647903214F94042.description:
Use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate
the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context.

18DED75D185A43FFA4D1B2EADFC4006B.description:
Define the six inverse trigonometric functions using domain restrictions for regions where the
function is always increasing or always decreasing.

18ACC3EA52C84A5689F3E40A5E68D562.description:
Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude,
frequency, and midline.

EE22C69493A04D4EB54FE87415144C34.description:
Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric
functions.

B0EF190E5EDF43F9B2F9325E183A494C.description:
Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent for ùúã
3
,
ùúã
4
,
and ùúã
6
, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, and tangent for ùúã ‚àí ùë•, ùúã + ùë•,
and 2ùúã ‚àí ùë• in terms of their values for ùë•, where ùë• is any real number.

8066094C60B0497F8CB738826F7E2D42.description:
Write cotangent, secant, and cosecant functions as the reciprocals of tangent, cosine,
and sine, respectively.

3A0EBC015E464720A9FA0CF79CD55F1F.description:
Define the tangent, cotangent, secant, and cosecant functions as ratios involving sine
and cosine.

286C54512AD34BBFBC91279304F2C421.description:
Define sine and cosine as functions of the radian measure of an angle in terms of the ùë•- and ùë¶-
coordinates of the point on the unit circle corresponding to that angle and explain how these
definitions are extensions of the right triangle definitions.

5332E71A2E7B41E9A93340B13D7B0B61.description:
Understand that the radian measure of an angle is the length of the arc on the unit circle
subtended by the angle.

DD2A1528260848BFAD7E9FCE1B31E7B3.description: Using technology, compute and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.

43B330CD445149CEACFFFE237E3BC6D3.description:
Create a linear function to graphically model data from a real-world problem and interpret the meaning of the

slope and intercept(s) in the context of the given problem.

3E62E4450A4F4896B1AAA030830BCFFE.description:
Using technology, create scatterplots and analyze those plots to compare the fit of linear, quadratic, or
exponential models to a given data set. Select the appropriate model, fit a function to the data set, and use the
function to solve problems in the context of the data.

B43F597E5409401E963E243035F30554.description:
Explain why the sum or product of rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number and an
irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is
irrational.

57A0B89DBA1745318989791F6DAB9937.description: Use the definition of the meaning of rational exponents to translate between rational exponent and radical forms.

2ED012A5A0A546F2B958E6038C8C55AE.description: Rewrite expressions involving simple radicals and rational exponents in different forms.

D3CA829D99B940BD950CFFA85B6AB91D.description: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities in context.

AC74D54F03914F8BB10B126A5AC86330.description: Label and define appropriate quantities in descriptive modeling contexts.

7B22AF982DA14749BA7E7AB28CCC195A.description:
Use units of measurement to guide the solution of multi-step tasks. Choose and interpret appropriate labels, units,

and scales when constructing graphs and other data displays.

2B9D6FDFC717402A8788891B3921019A.description: ¬†Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function in terms of the context.¬†

7B534500964F443FA1731EF2E28487D9.description:
Express a logarithm as the solution to the exponential equation, ùëéùëèùëêùë° = ùëë where ùëé, ùëê, and ùëë are
numbers and the base ùëè is 2, 10, or ùëí; evaluate the logarithm using technology

A7A811A1F7714CC198EE3894A3408E3D.description:
Observe using graphs and tables that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a
quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or more generally as a polynomial function.

C2E3318233AF47F9A2529138E16FE0FB.description:
Create symbolic representations of linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and
geometric sequences, given graphs, verbal descriptions, and tables.¬†

4302389441E54DD98539870B5AE3AA09.description:
Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per
unit interval relative toFLQE.1*b another.

E506A60802D44EA2BF6CD66B5A878DA9.description:
Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals and that
exponential functions grow by equal factors over equal intervals.

082BCF7CF56B4C17A0B04AB74B202D3A.description:
Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions or exponential
functions by recognizing situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit
interval as opposed to those in which a quantity changes by a constant percent rate per unit
interval. (Note: FLQE.1a and 1b are not Graduation Standards.)

D4EE4CB15E2E4E6F9A6CDA1A0AC1399E.description:
Compare properties of two functions given in different representations such as algebraic,
graphical, tabular, or verbal.¬†

28A8BEAFDFF449AF8283C47DEE53147C.description: Interpret expressions for exponential functions by using the properties of exponents

14D57ACE19C04A00BD02EC19CDB263EB.description:
Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show
zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a
context.

B6B97867442944FA84FD5B20918B0FDA.description:
Translate between different but equivalent forms of a function equation to reveal and explain
different properties of the function. (Note: FIF.8a and 8b are not Graduation Standards.)

DB459DCBAC6B4B3B99A54FB602985001.description: Graph trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude.

0E090ED55CD64F9AB588F4E524469EB9.description: Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts and end behavior

A1A718B990E44AA889BD8B6D1E307E9D.description: Graph radical functions over their domain show end behavior.

4ECAE92632F84D2780609CA9C9474FEB.description:
Graph rational functions, identifying zeros and asymptotes when suitable factorizations
are available, and showing end behavior.

01607744308342F29F0CDE0B312CDA27.description:
Graph functions from their symbolic representations. Indicate key features including intercepts;
intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or negative; relative maximums
and minimums; symmetries; end behavior and periodicity. Graph simple cases by hand and use
technology for complicated cases. (Note: FIF.7a ‚Äì d are not Graduation Standards.)

0CB6114448884E72A4A0F0C0D6D2153D.description:
Given a function in graphical, symbolic, or tabular form, determine the average rate of change of
the function over a specified interval. Interpret the meaning of the average rate of change in a
given context.

16BEE3970EBA4AD4AE509BFF727B496C.description:
Relate the domain and range of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative
relationship it describes.¬†

8C51A57C8AB243929AC0BC763C9F0FD9.description:
Interpret key features of a function that models the relationship between two quantities when
given in graphical or tabular form. Sketch the graph of a function from a verbal description
showing key features. Key features include intercepts; intervals where the function is increasing,
decreasing, constant, positive, or negative; relative maximums and minimums; symmetries; end
behavior and periodicity.¬†

8E5CB4114C314B0283AF8432067037C9.description:
Define functions recursively and recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined
recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers.

C7A8795283B842488C26597F46D1D452.description:
Evaluate functions and interpret the meaning of expressions involving function notation from a
mathematical perspective and in terms of the context when the function describes a real-world
situation.

1AB70770D50E45CCAD476CB7DDB1F1A4.description:
Understand that the graph of a function labeled as ùëì is the set of all ordered pairs (ùë•, ùë¶)
that satisfy the equation ùë¶ = ùëì(ùë•).¬†

8E4ECB891DE649B8BBE99828C348DD1F.description:
Represent a function using function notation and explain that ùëì(ùë•) denotes the output
of function ùëì that corresponds to the input ùë•.¬†

B964362DFA9540D08BA286C2DD2E6BA9.description:
Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the
range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range.¬†

C86950E2C6FC4C82BF5C5A7B7F562826.description: Extend previous knowledge of a function to apply to general behavior and features of a function.

144FBAB44C2B4DBA999C529BCC997A7F.description:
Understand and verify through function composition that exponential and logarithmic functions
are inverses of each other and use this relationship to solve problems involving logarithms and
exponents.

55995911DECA4A46BF63B4E42C86E483.description: If a function has an inverse, find values of the inverse function from a graph or table.

679A4DDE74A54959A600BAF420F996AC.description: Use composition to verify one function is an inverse of another

A9155BBC863F490684A9AF523BDBB095.description:
Understand that an inverse function can be obtained by expressing the dependent variable of one
function as the independent variable of another, as ùëì and ùëî are inverse functions if and only if
ùëì(ùë•) = ùë¶ and ùëî(ùë¶) = ùë•, for all values of ùë• in the domain of ùëì and all values of ùë¶ in the domain
of ùëî, and find inverse functions for one-to-one function or by restricting the domain.

373D344C182A4A9CA0934DC79E97C5D3.description:
Describe the effect of the transformations ùëòùëì(ùë•), ùëì(ùë•) + ùëò, ùëì(ùë• + ùëò), and combinations of such
transformations on the graph of ùë¶ = ùëì(ùë•) for any real number ùëò. Find the value of ùëò given the
graphs and write the equation of a transformed parent function given its graph.¬†

2E7733AD0AE143D9B92754218B3E0584.description:
Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula, use
them to model situations, and translate between the two forms.¬†

7364CD9B48A54FA4B338486E9028B564.description:
Combine functions using the operations addition, subtraction, multiplication, and
division to build new functions that describe the relationship between two quantities in
mathematical and real-world situations.

BAC72F6324DD491F9705D780F0458791.description:
Write a function that models a relationship between two quantities using both explicit
expressions and a recursive process and by combining standard forms using addition,
subtraction, multiplication and division to build new functions.¬†

E565CBE698B54055B291E4A00BFD5C0A.description:
Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities.
(Note: FBF.1a is not a Graduation Standard.)

368792D4B7834EB9A9D3AD46E3F2E6F0.description:
Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series (when the common ratio is not 1), and
use the formula to solve problems including applications to finance.

782F86389E1840FC87A79C5226962DCE.description: Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions.¬†

EBC9712EA78F4ABD8E53CDED5C0EF91B.description:
Determine the maximum or minimum value of a quadratic function by completing the
square.¬†

5B5879D90038424681FC77A3C9C4C935.description:
Find the zeros of a quadratic function by rewriting it in equivalent factored form and
explain the connection between the zeros of the function, its linear factors, the xintercepts of its graph, and the solutions to the corresponding quadratic equation.

304CAE05B4EC477BA604C644DC00F929.description:
Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the
quantity represented by the expression. (Note: ASE.3b and 3c are not Graduation Standards.)

2058F04EA78E4CACB6EF403EC2BC6B6C.description:
Analyze the structure of binomials, trinomials, and other polynomials in order to rewrite
equivalent expressions.

39A3B374D8CE4DC082DC429F4588D7F8.description:
Interpret the meanings of coefficients, factors, terms, and expressions based on their real-world
contexts. Interpret complicated expressions as being composed of simpler expressions.¬†

1016753D83D84404B1DB2F5FCACCDA2B.description: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables.

418C538471E24357AA78BE7FA78BD881.description:
Solve an equation of the form ùëì(ùë•) = ùëî(ùë•) graphically by identifying the ùë•-coordinate(s) of the
point(s) of intersection of the graphs of ùë¶ = ùëì(ùë•) and ùë¶ = ùëî(ùë•).¬†

7F8EF50BB7AE4C7D9CBA367D6F09C0E2.description:
Explain that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the
coordinate plane.

78A1E83527E043AA9C9BF8F7254EFFBF.description:
Using technology for matrices of dimension 3 √ó 3 or greater, find the inverse of a matrix if it
exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations.

1191E136F9334146ACDE7D223BD508F6.description: Represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable.

E33E5D074A884DD4ABDC8E7920CCDB4C.description:
Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables
algebraically and graphically. Understand that such systems may have zero, one, two, or
infinitely many solutions.¬†

86F7CB50C2854F8EA50648CD96942131.description: Solve systems of linear equations using linear combination.

AD78AB02488C497396388DE2B10F32C2.description: Solve systems of linear equations using the substitution method.

D097F02E72DA4A42882D5F190ED73B44.description:
Solve systems of linear equations algebraically and graphically focusing on pairs of linear
equations in two variables. (Note: AREI.6a and 6b are not Graduation Standards.)

D1DEA61B9BAC47ECAB4591B66180C905.description:
Justify that the solution to a system of linear equations is not changed when one of the equations
is replaced by a linear combination of the other equation.

6070875CB7FF4D2E9C6CC307A981C8F5.description:
Solve quadratic equations by inspection, taking square roots, completing the square,
the quadratic formula and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation.
Recognize when the quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as
ùëé + ùëèùëñ for real numbers ùëé and ùëè.¬†

2563C1B0EA1A464A920ACA3701BC99B2.description:
Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in ùë• into
an equation of the form (ùë• ‚àí ‚Ñé)2¬† = ùëò that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic
formula from this form.

E7EB62D26B0E45E8A5C80786755436D7.description:
Solve mathematical and real-world problems involving quadratic equations in one variable.
(Note: AREI.4a and 4b are not Graduation Standards.)

D98589524E244B8996C8F2BCCC7346B9.description:
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients
represented by letters.

281E607B02384C2A99C2905B58571A92.description:
Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable and understand how extraneous
solutions may arise.

3A37C2196DC84D17B992C4EDF0E0BA30.description:
Understand and justify that the steps taken when solving simple equations in one variable create
new equations that have the same solution as the original.¬†

254FD39AEAA5423B84802493997DA035.description:
Solve literal equations and formulas for a specified variable including equations and formulas
that arise in a variety of disciplines.

7B7A6B3445134C92917C489FBBF3BF5E.description:
Use systems of equations and inequalities to represent constraints arising in real-world situations.
Solve such systems using graphical and analytical methods, including linear programing.
Interpret the solution within the context of the situation.¬†

C17AAE3FDC45401AAB4ABF4FECDC427D.description:
Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities. Graph
the equations on coordinate axes using appropriate labels, units, and scales.¬†

A6DEFA225D494C9F827B222632B443A0.description:
Create and solve equations and inequalities in one variable that model real-world problems
involving linear, quadratic, simple rational, and exponential relationships. Interpret the solutions
and determine whether they are reasonable.

C7170F73B0EA4AFABA9BEB9EF2F829CB.description:
Understand that rational expressions form a system analogous to the rational numbers, closed
under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by a nonzero rational expression; add,
subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.

5EADA399C8DF4CBE821EAFFF97D460B1.description:
Apply algebraic techniques to rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms; using
inspection, long division, or, for the more complicated examples, a computer algebra system.

E2C795E6349D4D1198962B0AEAC4077E.description:
Apply the Binomial Theorem to expand powers of binomials, including those with one and with
two variables. Use the Binomial Theorem to factor squares, cubes, and fourth powers of
binomials.

D363D7CF6908408B90939120A14F1169.description: Prove polynomial identities and use them to describe numerical relationships.¬†

AE61CA54FC9A44F3A141E8D99A19CCB3.description:
Graph polynomials identifying zeros when suitable factorizations are available and indicating
end behavior. Write a polynomial function of least degree corresponding to a given graph.¬†

6D8D7F7A1EF1438B950ACD7E6695E8C4.description: Know and apply the Division Theorem and the Remainder Theorem for polynomials.

8204A34538334B4DBA574BD0B51A424A.description:
Add, subtract, and multiply polynomials and understand that polynomials are closed under these
operations.

38C5EA14D5B946FFAADDF60B18E51730.description: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions
